references: Irwin, K.J. and F.W. Judd. 2005. Notophthalmus meridionalis (Cope 1880), Black-spotted Newt. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 884-887.
Mecham, J. S. 1967. Notophthalmus meridionalis. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles. p. 38.
IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
habitat_description: Black-spotted newts occur in southeastern Texas south to central eastern Mexico and inhabit both ephemeral and permanent ponds and wetlands where water levels can be > 60 cm and contain heavy amounts of submergent vegetation (Mecham 1968, Petranka 1998). Mecham (1968) suggests that juveniles will remain aquatic until reproductively mature or until breeding habitat dries up, wherein overland travel for cover is required (Irwin and Judd 2005). Deep, poorly drained clayey sediment soil types with poor permeability are important for this species to maintain ephmeral ponds and wetlands. Intact Tamaulipan thorn forest in such soils with ephemeral wetlands is optimal adult habitat (Irwin and Judd 2005).
